questions.text: Identify the thyroid malignancy from the X-ray shown below:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Follicular carcinoma The image shows follicular carcinoma of the thyroid with skull secondaries Follicular carcinoma can typically only be differentiated from follicular adenoma by the architecture of histology. For this reason, follicular lesions on FNA cannot be diagnosed as malignant without clinical features such as metastases. Multiple foci of follicular carcinoma are seldom seen, and lymph node involvement is much less common than in papillary carcinoma. Blood-borne metastases are more common, and the eventual mortality rate, although still low, is twice that of papillary cancer. Hürthle cell tumors are a rare variant of follicular neoplasm in which oxyphil (Hürthle, Askanazy) cells predominate histologically. Hürthle cell cancers are associated with a poorer prognosis.

Highyeild:

Follicular carcinoma of the thyroid Follicular thyroid carcinoma (FTC) is the second most common, accounting for 10% of thyroid cancer cases. FTC occurs more commonly in iodine-deficient areas. FTC is more common in women, with a mean age of 50 at diagnosis. Several genes have been implicated in FTC, including p53, PTEN, RAS, and PAX8/PPAR1.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Papillary carcinoma Papillary thyroid carcinoma ( PTC) is the most common thyroid malignancy , and it is known for its propensity for lymph node metastases . Despite occult micrometastases, few patients progress to have the clinically meaningful disease, and the role of elective nodal surgery is in question. Option: C. Medullary carcinoma Medullary carcinomas are parafollicular (C cells) tumors derived from the neural crest that are not unlike those of a carcinoid tumor. They may occur in combination with adrenal phaeochromocytoma and hyperparathyroidism in a syndrome known as multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2A (MEN-2A). Option: D. Anaplastic carcinoma This type of thyroid cancer is responsible for 1% of all cases. Women in their 70s and 80s are primarily affected by this cancer. Patients with this cancer usually have a neck mass that has been present for a long time but suddenly becomes larger and possibly painful. This is the most aggressive form of thyroid cancer.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presented with Hypertension, headache, muscle weakness, and nocturia. CT abdomen of the patient shows:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Conn syndrome The image shows a computed tomography scan of Conn's adenoma of the left adrenal gland . Conn’s syndrome: Incidence: Primary hyperaldosteronism (PHA) is defined by hypertension as a result of aldosterone hypersecretion. In PHA, plasma renin activity is suppressed. Among patients with hypertension, the incidence of PHA is approximately 2%. Clinical features: Most patients are between 30 and 50 years of age, with a female predominance. Apart from hypertension, patients complain of non-specific symptoms: headache, muscle weakness, cramps, neurological events, polyuria, polydipsia, and nocturia. Diagnosis : The key feature of the biochemical diagnosis is the assessment of the aldosterone-to-plasma renin activity ratio. Hypokalaemia may be present. Antihypertensive and diuretic therapy , which cause hypokalaemia and influence the renin–angiotensin aldosterone system, must be discontinued. Once the biochemical diagnosis is confirmed, MRI or CT should be performed to distinguish unilateral from bilateral disease. Conn’s adenomas usually measure between 1 and 2 cm and are detected by CT with a sensitivity of 80–90%.

Highyeild:

Conn's syndrome, also known as primary hyperaldosteronism, is a medical condition characterized by excess aldosterone production by the adrenal glands. In Conn's syndrome, excess aldosterone production increases sodium retention and potassium excretion, which can result in high blood pressure, low potassium levels, and metabolic alkalosis (an elevated pH in the blood). a benign tumor most commonly causes Conn's syndrome in one of the adrenal glands, known as an aldosterone-producing adenoma. It can also be caused by hyperplasia (overgrowth) of the adrenal glands, which can be either unilateral or bilateral. In rare cases, Conn's syndrome can be caused by a genetic mutation that affects the regulation of aldosterone production.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Incidentaloma An adrenal mass found on imaging that was not conducted to diagnose adrenal disease is an incidentaloma. The cause of such a mass can be either a benign or malignant tumor of the cortex or medulla, or it can originate outside the adrenal gland. These tumors may or may not secrete hormones and can be classified as either non-functioning (inactive) or functioning (excess hormone secretion). Option: C. Cushing syndrome Hypercortisolism is caused by excess ACTH secretion due to various factors, including pituitary-dependent and pituitary-independent Cushing's syndrome. ACTH-secreting pituitary tumors are the most common cause. Left untreated, hypercortisolism increases the risk of death from cardiovascular disease. Identifying and treating the underlying cause is essential while minimizing long-term hormonal deficiency or dependence on medication. Option: D. Adrenocortical carcinoma Adrenocortical carcinoma (ACC) is a rare and aggressive cancer that develops in the adrenal cortex. The prognosis for ACC is generally poor, partly due to late diagnosis. ACC can occur sporadically but can also be associated with specific genetic tumor syndromes. Optimal surgery is the best chance for a cure, making preoperative diagnosis and planning crucial for successful treatment.

Extraedge:

Treatment for Conn's syndrome typically involves surgery to remove the affected adrenal gland if a tumor or hyperplasia is present. In some cases, medications may also help manage blood pressure and potassium levels.

questions.text: Oral mucosal neurinomas shown in the following image are associated with the following:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

MEN 2B MEN 1 is characterized by the triad of tumors in the anterior pituitary gland , mostly presenting as prolactinomas or non-functioning tumors , hyperplasia of the parathyroids causing primary hyperparathyroidism (pHPT), and pancreaticoduodenal endocrine tumors (PETs). The syndrome was first described by Wermer in 1954 and is therefore also called Wermer’s syndrome . It is caused by germline mutations in the menin gene located on chromosome 11. MEN 2 is divided into three subtypes : familial medullary thyroid carcinoma (FMTC), MEN 2A, and MEN 2B . Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) plays a vital role in all subtypes. MEN 2 is caused by germline mutations in the RET proto-oncogene located on chromosome 10. MEN 2A is characterized by MTC, pHPT, and mostly bilateral phaeochromocytomas. MTC combined with phaeochromocytomas alone is called Sipple’s syndrome . Familial medullary thyroid carcinoma (FMTC) is characterized by distinct mutations in RET and MTC independently as the clinical manifestation. MEN 2B comprises MTC, phaeochromocytoma, characteristic facial and oral mucosal neurinomas, and intestinal ganglion-pneumatosis , accompanied by a Marfanoid habitus . Besides the different clinical pictures, the most crucial difference between MEN 1 and MEN 2 , besides the other clinical pictures, is that MEN 2 is characterized by a well-understood genotype–phenotype correlation. This means that depending on the particular mutation in the RET proto-oncogene, the phenotypic appearance and the onset of endocrine tumors will be different and can be predicted from the type of mutation. This is not the case in MEN 1 syndrome.

Highyeild:

MEN 2B is resulting from RET mutations and is responsible for a prevalence of 0.2 per 100,000 individuals. MEN 2B has an early-onset and aggressive form of MTC (present in 100% of cases), PPGL (present in 59% of cases), a marfanoid habitus, and the presence of ganglioneuromatosis in the oral mucosa and gastrointestinal tract. However, unlike other subtypes, half of MEN 2B cases are due to new mutations not inherited from either parent. Familial MTC (FMTC), a form of MEN 2, only presents with MTC without additional endocrine tumors. When MTC is combined with PCC, the condition is called Sipple's syndrome.

Extraedge:

Most individuals affected by MEN 2 develop medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC), the main factor determining their survival. Although pheochromocytomas (PCCs) are typically noncancerous and less likely malignant in individuals with MEN 2, they tend to affect both adrenal glands. Primary hyperparathyroidism (PHPT) in MEN 2 is generally asymptomatic and may not require surgery.

questions.text: The following sign is suggestive of
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Chronic pancreatitis The image shows Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography of chronic pancreatitis . Long stricture of the pancreatic duct in the head; the distal pancreatic duct shows sacculation with intervening short strictures and a ‘chain of lakes' appearance .

Highyeild:

Chronic pancreatitis refers to an ongoing inflammatory condition of the pancreas that results in irreversible structural changes, often leading to pain and permanent loss of function. While some individuals with chronic pancreatitis experience painful episodes, others may not experience any pain at all.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Acute pancreatitis Acute pancreatitis is a sudden onset inflammation of the pancreas caused by the activation of pancreatic enzymes within the gland. The most common cause of acute pancreatitis is gallstone disease, followed by alcohol abuse. Option: C. Pancreatic necrosis Pancreatic necrosis is a severe complication of acute pancreatitis that occurs when pancreas areas become necrotic or die. Pancreatic necrosis can be either sterile or infected, with the latter being more severe and potentially life-threatening. Symptoms of pancreatic necrosis include persistent abdominal pain, fever, and signs of systemic inflammation.

Extraedge:

Chronic pancreatitis is confirmed by pancreatic insufficiency or significant gland destruction, not serum amylase levels. Pancreatic calcifications may be visible on abdominal X-rays, while CT or MRI scans can reveal gland damage and potential for surgery. MRCP helps identify the biliary obstruction and duct condition, and ERCP helps determine the necessary operation.

questions.text: FNAC is not useful in which thyroid cancer
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Follicular carcinoma FNAC is both highly specific and sensitive. Using ultrasound improves this further, particularly in part cystic, part-solid nodules in which ultrasound allows targeting of the solid element for biopsy. FNAC should be used, under USG guidance, on all nodules that do not fulfill a fully benign classification on ultrasound. FNAC is reliable in identifying papillary thyroid cancer but cannot distinguish between a benign follicular adenoma and follicular carcinoma. This distinction depends not on cytology but on histological criteria, including capsular and vascular invasion.

Highyeild:

Follicular carcinoma of thyroid Follicular thyroid carcinoma (FTC) is the second most common, accounting for 10% of thyroid cancer cases. FTC occurs more commonly in iodine-deficient areas. FTC is more common in women , with a mean age of 50 at diagnosis. Several genes have been implicated in FTC, including p53, PTEN, RAS, and PAX8/PPAR1. FTC is difficult to distinguish from benign thyroid diseases, and a surgical procedure to remove all or part of the thyroid gland may be required for a definitive diagnosis. Despite its well-differentiated characteristics, FTC can spread quickly to other organs, with older patients having an increased risk of developing bone and lung metastases.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. Papillary carcinoma PTC is the most common thyroid malignancy, and it is known for its propensity for lymph node metastases . Despite occult micrometastases, few patients progress to have the clinically meaningful disease, and the role of elective nodal surgery is in question. Option: C. Medullary carcinoma Medullary carcinomas are parafollicular (C cells) tumors derived from the neural crest that are not unlike those of a carcinoid tumor. They may occur in combination with adrenal phaeochromocytoma and hyperparathyroidism in a syndrome known as multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2A (MEN-2A). Option: D. Thyroid lymphoma Thyroid lymphoma is a rare malignancy, accounting for less than 5% of all thyroid malignancies. It is most commonly associated with non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, and the most frequent subtype is diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Patients typically present with a rapidly enlarging goiter and compressive symptoms, with or without systemic symptoms.

questions.text: The Dunhill procedure of thyroidectomy is
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Near-total thyroidectomy All thyroid operations can be assembled from three essential elements: Total lobectomy Isthmusectomy Subtotal lobectomy Total thyroidectomy=2 × total lobectomy + isthmus ectomy Subtotal thyroidectomy = 2 subtotal lobectomy + isthmus ectomy Near-total thyroidectomy = total lobectomy + isthmus ectomy + subtotal lobectomy (Dunhill procedure) Lobectomy = total lobectomy + isthmus ectomy.

Highyeild:

Thyroid surgeries such as total and near-total thyroidectomy remove a significant portion of thyroid tissue, which can compromise normal thyroid function. As a result, patients may require thyroid replacement therapy. However, in cases where patients have negative antithyroid antibodies, research suggests that one thyroid lobe may be able to sustain normal thyroid function in approximately two-thirds of cases.

questions.text: True statement regarding Riedel’s thyroiditis is/are

options.label: A
options.text: May associate with Retroperitoneal and mediastinal fibrosis

options.label: B
options.text: The differential diagnosis is Anaplastic carcinoma

questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above Riedel’s thyroiditis: Thyroid tissue is replaced by cellular fibrous tissue , which infiltrates through the capsule into muscles and adjacent structures, including parathyroids, recurrent nerves, and carotid sheath. It may be associated with retroperitoneal and mediastinal fibrosis and is probably a collagen disease. Goitre may be unilateral or bilateral and is very hard and fixed. The differential diagnosis from anaplastic carcinoma can be made with certainty only by biopsy when a wedge of the isthmus should also be removed to free the trachea. Treatment is with high-dose steroids, tamoxifen, and thyroxine replacement.

Highyeild:

Fibrous thyroiditis is a rare type of goiter, accounting for only 0.5% of cases. In this condition, the thyroid tissue is replaced by fibrous tissue infiltrating through the capsule into adjacent structures such as muscles, parathyroids, recurrent nerves, and the carotid sheath. Fibrous thyroiditis may be associated with retroperitoneal and mediastinal fibrosis and is likely a collagen disease. The goiter can be unilateral or bilateral and is hard and fixed. If unilateral, the other lobe becomes involved later, and subsequent hypothyroidism is common.

Extraedge:

A biopsy is necessary to differentiate fibrous thyroiditis from anaplastic carcinoma, and a wedge of the isthmus should also be removed to free the trachea. Treatment for fibrous thyroiditis involves high-dose steroids, tamoxifen, and thyroxine replacement. Early treatment can lead to a reduction in goiter size and long-term symptom improvement.

questions.text: False about Subacute thyroiditis is/are:

options.label: B
options.text: Pain in the neck, fever, and malaise are typical presentations

options.label: C
options.text: I-123 uptake of the gland is low

questions.explanation:
Solution:

None of the above Granulomatous thyroiditis (subacute thyroiditis, de Quervain’s thyroiditis): This may follow a viral infection. In a typical subacute presentation, there is pain in the neck, fever, malaise, and a firm, irregular enlargement of one or both thyroid lobes. There are raised inflammatory markers, absent thyroid antibodies, the serum T4 is high standard or slightly raised, and the I 123 uptake of the gland is low. The condition is self-limiting; the goiter subsides in a few months, and there may be months of hypothyroidism before eventual recovery. In 10% of cases, the onset is acute, the goiter very painful and tender, and there may be symptoms of hyperthyroidism. If the diagnosis is in doubt, it may be confirmed by FNAC , radioactive iodine uptake, and rapid symptomatic response to prednisone . The specific treatment for the acute case with severe pain is to give prednisone 10–20mg daily for seven days, and the dose is then gradually reduced over the next month. If thyroid failure is prominent, treatment with thyroxine may be required until function recovers.

Highyeild:

Subacute thyroiditis can follow a viral infection and presents with neck pain, fever, malaise, and irregular enlargement of one or both thyroid lobes. Inflammatory markers are elevated, thyroid antibodies are absent, serum T4 levels are high standard or slightly raised, and 123I uptake of the gland is low. The goiter is self-limiting, subsiding in a few months, and may be followed by hypothyroidism before eventual recovery. In 10% of cases, the onset is acute and painful, with symptoms of hyperthyroidism. One-third of cases are asymptomatic, except for the presence of the goiter.

Extraedge:

FNAC, radioactive iodine uptake, and rapid response to prednisone can confirm the diagnosis. Specific treatment for acute patients with severe pain involves 10-20 mg of prednisone daily for seven days, gradually reducing the dose over the next month. Thyroxine may be required for patients with prominent thyroid failure until function recovers.

questions.text: Struma lymphomatosis is also known as
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hashimoto's thyroiditis Chronic lymphocytic/ autoimmune thyroiditis/ HASHIMOTO'S thyroiditis: This common condition is usually associated with raised titers of thyroid antibodies. It commonly presents as a goiter, which may be diffuse or nodular with a characteristic ‘bosselated’ feel or with established or subclinical thyroid failure. On histological examination: Intense lymphocytic-plasma cell infiltration, acinar destruction, and fibrosis. This condition is also known as ' Struma Lymphomatosa .' Primary myxoedema without detectable thyroid enlargement represents the end stage of the pathological process.

Highyeild:

A condition associated with raised thyroid antibodies Commonly presents as a goiter (diffuse or nodular) Goitre may have a characteristic 'bosselated' feel Can cause established or subclinical thyroid failure Often diagnosed after investigation of a swelling

It may be associated with retroperitoneal and mediastinal fibrosis and is probably a collagen disease. Option: C. de Quervain's thyroiditis Option: D. Medullary carcinoma

Chronic lymphocytic (focal) thyroiditis features are commonly present on histological examination. Associated with other thyroid diseases, notably toxic goiter

questions.text: Most common surgical approach in accessing retrosternal goiter is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cervical Mediastinal goiter can be divided into: Primary: Only <1% of mediastinal goiters , arising from ectopic thyroid tissue in the mediastinum with blood supply from mediastinal vessels Secondary: Majority of mediastinal goiters due to the extension of thyroid from neck with blood supply from thyroid arteries. Treatment: The vast majority (>95%) of retrosternal goiters can be removed trans-cervically. Those at most risks of requiring conversion to an open sternotomy approach include malignant or revision cases, those which extend into the posterior mediastinum, and those in which the diameter of the goiter exceeds that of the thoracic inlet. In such cases, a joint case with thoracic surgery should be planned.

Primary Mediastinal Goiters Secondary Mediastinal Goiters Frequency Approximately 1% Majority Origin Arise from ectopic thyroid tissue in the chest Arise from downward extension of cervical thyroid tissue along the fascial planes of the neck Blood supply Supplied by intrathoracic blood vessels Derive their blood supply from superior and inferior thyroid arteries Connection to thyroid tissue in the neck No connection Connected to thyroid tissue in the neck Size Variable Variable

questions.text: A 50 years old female patient presented with a mass in front of the neck revealed parafollicular cells. How do you follow up?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Calcitonin Medullary carcinoma: 5% of all thyroid malignancies It arises from Parafollicular 'C' cells It is associated with MEN2A &MEN2B syndromes RET - proto-oncogene mutation is seen in familial variety. (RET gene located in centromere region of chromosome 10) Diagnosis: FNAC- Amyloid. CEA is better for prognosis. Calcitonin is better for follow-up.

Highyeild:

Calcitonin is a hormone produced by the thyroid gland's parafollicular cells (also called C-cells). Its main function is to regulate calcium and phosphate levels in the blood by inhibiting bone resorption and promoting renal excretion of calcium. High calcitonin levels are also associated with certain thyroid tumors, particularly medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC). Measurement of serum calcitonin levels is used as a tumor marker for MTC and can also be used to monitor treatment response.

Extraedge:

In patients with a family history of MTC, screening for the RET proto-oncogene mutation and measurement of baseline calcitonin levels is recommended. Treatment for MTC usually involves surgical resection of the thyroid gland, with possible additional treatments such as chemotherapy or radiation therapy depending on the stage and extent of the tumor.

questions.text: Lateral Aberrant thyroid refers to

options.label: D
options.text: Metastatic foci from the primary in thyroid

questions.correct_answer: D. Metastatic foci from the primary in thyroid
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Metastatic foci from the primary in thyroid “ Lateral aberrant thyroid ” almost always denotes a cervical lymph node invaded by metastatic cancer. Suspicion of thyroid cancer often originates through physical examination of patients and a review of their history. Diagnosis is established by FNAC of the thyroid mass or lymph node. Once thyroid cancer is diagnosed on FNAC, a complete neck ultrasound is strongly recommended to evaluate the contralateral lobe and for lymph node metastases in the central and lateral neck compartments. Distant metastases are uncommon at initial presentation, but may ultimately develop in up to 20% of patients. The most common sites are the lungs, bone, liver, and brain .

Highyeild:

Lateral aberrant thyroid: Any thyroid tissue found laterally separate from the thyroid gland is always considered to be metastasis in a cervical lymph node, as aberrant thyroid tissue never occurs in a lateral position. Aberrant thyroid tissues are found along the course of the thyroglossal tract: Lingual Cervical Thoracic Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid is MC associated with lateral aberrant thyroid

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option A: Lingual thyroid is when the thyroid doesn't descend properly and may be the only thyroid tissue present Intervention is needed for obstructive symptoms like choking, dysphagia, airway obstruction, or bleeding Patients may develop hypothyroidism Option B : A congenital thyroid anomaly can include a range of conditions, such as an absent or ectopic thyroid gland, abnormal thyroid hormone production or metabolism, or abnormal thyroid growth or structure. Option C : Struma ovarii is a benign ovarian tumor containing thyroid tissue The tumor is solid and consists entirely of thyroid tissue Some cases develop thyrotoxicosis. Most of the tumor is innocent, but malignant transformations have been recorded

questions.text: Psammoma bodies are seen in all of the following except
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Follicular carcinoma of thyroid Histopathology of Papillary carcinoma: On gross examination, PTCs generally are hard and whitish and remain flat on sectioning with a blade, in contrast to normal tissue or benign nodular lesions that tend to bulge. Macroscopic calcification, necrosis, or cystic change may be apparent. Histologically, papillary carcinomas may exhibit papillary projections , a mixed pattern of papillary and follicular structures, or a pure follicular pattern (follicular variant). Characteristic nuclear cellular features establish the diagnosis. Cells are cuboidal with pale, abundant cytoplasm, crowded nuclei that may demonstrate “ grooving ,” and intranuclear cytoplasmic inclusions (leading to the designation of Orphan Annie nuclei), which allow diagnosis by FNAC. Psammoma bodies , microscopic, calcified deposits representing clumps of sloughed cells, may also be present. It may also be seen in the ovary's papillary type of Renal adenocarcinoma, Meningioma, and serous cystadenoma. Mixed papillary-follicular tumors and follicular variants of papillary carcinoma are classified as papillary carcinomas because they behave biologically as papillary carcinomas. Multifocality is common in papillary carcinoma and may be present in up to 85% of cases on microscopic examination. Multifocality is associated with an increased risk of cervical nodal metastases, and these tumors may rarely invade adjacent structures such as the trachea, esophagus, and RLNs.

Highyeild:

Follicular carcinoma of thyroid Follicular thyroid carcinoma (FTC) is the second most common, accounting for 10% of thyroid cancer cases. FTC occurs more commonly in iodine-deficient areas. FTC is more common in women, with a mean age of 50 at diagnosis. Several genes have been implicated in FTC, including p53, PTEN, RAS, and PAX8/PPAR1.

questions.text: A patient with multinodular goitre developed pain and difficulty in breathing. Most common cancer to cause this complication
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Anaplastic carcinoma Undifferentiated (anaplastic) carcinoma: This is one of the most aggressive malignancies. It may develop de novo or present as dedifferentiation of a papillary or poorly differentiated carcinoma. The disease is characterized by rapid growth, visceral invasion, and distant metastases. Thyroid lymphoma can be incorrectly diagnosed as anaplastic cancer, and a biopsy is critical. This can be done using a core or open technique. Almost all patients will be dead within six months. Radiotherapy and chemotherapy have not been shown to improve survival. Those patients who have a known diagnosis and develop airway symptoms are generally better managed without tracheostomy; in patients who present with airway signs and without a diagnosis, a tracheostomy may be required to buy time to confirm the diagnosis.

Highyeild:

Anaplastic carcinoma: This type of thyroid cancer is responsible for 1% of all cases. Women in their 70s and 80s are primarily affected by this cancer. Patients with this cancer usually have a neck mass that has been present for a long time but suddenly becomes larger and possibly painful. This is the most aggressive form of thyroid cancer.

Extraedge:

Majority of the patient's treatment is palliative. Those who develop airway symptoms are generally better managed without tracheostomy, despite the potentially distressing mode of death.

questions.text: Thyroid storm during surgery is due to
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Inadequate preoperative preparation Thyragitation or depression, and cardiovascular and GI dysfunction, including hepatic failure. the solid storm is a condition of hyperthyroidism accompanied by fever and central nervous system Thyroid storm may be precipitated by abrupt cessation of anti-thyroid medications, infection, thyroid or non-thyroid surgery, and trauma in patients with untreated thyrotoxicosis. Occasionally thyroid storm may result from amiodarone administration or exposure to iodinated contrast agents or following RAI Therapy. Treatment: β-Blocker are given to reduce peripheral T4 to T3 conversion & decrease the hyperthyroid symptoms. Oxygen supplementation and haemo-dynamic support should be instituted. Nonaspirin compounds can be used to treat pyrexia, and Lugol’s iodine or sodium update (intravenously) should be administered to decrease iodine uptake and thyroid hormone secretion. PTU therapy blocks the formation of new thyroid hormones and reduces the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3. Corticosteroids often help prevent adrenal exhaustion and block hepatic thyroid hormone conversion.

Highyeild:

Thyroid storm , also known as a thyrotoxic crisis , is a severe form of hyperthyroidism and a medical emergency . The following are the treatment measures for thyroid storm: Propranolol , a non-selective beta blocker, is the most valuable measure in thyroid storm as most of the symptoms are due to adrenergic overactivity caused by increased tissue sensitivity to catecholamines in hyperthyroidism. Propylthiouracil is the antithyroid drug of choice for thyroid storm as it reduces hormone synthesis and the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3. Iodides such as potassium iodide or iopanoic acid can be used to inhibit further hormone release from the gland Corticosteroids like hydrocortisone can inhibit the release of thyroid hormone from the gland and peripheral conversion of T4 to T3. Other measures include diltiazem, antibiotics, anxiolytics rehydration, and external cooling.

questions.text: All are true about thyroid lymphoma except:

options.label: D
options.text: May present with respiratory distress and dysphagia

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Slow growing Thyroid Lymphoma: Lymphomas account for <1% of thyroid malignancies; most are of the non-Hodgkin’s B-cell type. Although the disease can arise from a generalized lymphomatous condition, most thyroid lymphomas develop in patients with chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis. Chronic antigenic lymphocyte stimulation has been suggested to result in lymphocyte transformation. Patients usually present with symptoms similar to those of patients with anaplastic carcinoma, although the rapidly enlarging neck mass often is painless. Patients may present with acute respiratory distress. Ultrasound can be useful for early diagnosis, and lymphoma is a well-defined hypoechoic mass. The diagnosis usually is suggested by FNAC, but FNAC can be nondiagnostic, particularly in low-grade lymphomas. Therefore, a needle core or open biopsy may be necessary for a definitive diagnosis. Patients with thyroid lymphoma respond rapidly to chemotherapy (CHOP—cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin, vincristine, and prednisone) Thyroidectomy and nodal resection are used to alleviate symptoms of airway obstruction in patients who do not respond quickly to the above regimens or who have completed the regimen before diagnosis.

Highyeild:

Thyroid lymphoma Thyroid lymphoma is primarily classified into primary and secondary thyroid lymphoma. The most common type of primary thyroid lymphoma is diffuse large B-cell lymphoma , which behaves aggressively compared to mucosa-associated lymphoid lymphoma. Majority of patients with thyroid lymphoma have thyroid disease along with cervical or mediastinal lymph nodes. This type of lymphoma is more common in females . Most thyroid lymphomas develop in patients with Chronic Lymphocytic Thyroiditis . Patients with hypothyroidism and evidence of autoimmune thyroiditis or Hashimoto's thyroiditis are at higher risk of developing thyroid lymphoma. Clinical features Rapidly enlarging neck mass , which is often painless . Patients may also present with acute respiratory distress, dysphagia, hoarseness, dyspnea with stridor, or dysphagia. The lymphomas are painless and associated with fever . Patients with thyroid lymphoma rarely present with hyperthyroidism but frequently have hypothyroidism. The diagnosis of thyroid lymphoma is confirmed by core-needle biopsy . Treatment : The primary treatment for thyroid lymphoma combines chemotherapy and external beam radiotherapy .

Extraedge:

Patients with thyroid lymphoma respond rapidly to chemotherapy , which includes cyclophosphamide , doxorubicin , vincristine , and prednisone . A combined treatment with radiotherapy and chemotherapy is often recommended to treat thyroid lymphoma. Surgical resection, including thyroidectomy and nodal dissection , is recommended in cases where the patient experiences pressure symptoms due to tumor growth.

questions.text: Radioiodine therapy is preferred for the treatment of

options.label: D
options.text: Diffuse toxic goiter in >45 years old

questions.correct_answer: D. Diffuse toxic goiter in >45 years old
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Diffuse toxic goiter in >45 years old Absolute contraindications to RAI: Women who are pregnant (or planning pregnancy within six months of treatment) or breastfeeding. Relative contraindications: Young patients (i.e., especially children and adolescents), those with thyroid nodules, and those with ophthalmopathy.

Highyeild:

Radionuclide scan of thyroid: While ultrasound is useful for anatomic evaluation, radionuclide scans assess thyroid function. Scans using I 123 and I 131 iodine are commonly performed to evaluate the functional status of the thyroid gland. I 123 scans have the advantage of using a low dose of radiation (30 rad) and have a short half-life. In contrast, I 131 scans have a longer half-life (8 days) and emit higher levels of β-radiation. I 131 scans are optimal for imaging thyroid carcinoma and are the preferred screening modality for evaluating distant metastasis. I 131 is a highly effective agent for delivering high radiation doses to thyroid tissue. It primarily emits beta radiation (90%), which only penetrates up to 0.5 mm of tissue. This allows for therapeutic effects on the thyroid gland without causing damage to surrounding structures, especially the parathyroid glands.

questions.text: False about the surgical approach in thyroid surgery:

options.label: A
options.text: Incision is made 1cm below cricoid cartilage

options.label: C
options.text: For lobectomy thyroid is dissected at the isthmus

options.label: D
options.text: Strap muscles are divided if greater exposure is needed

questions.correct_answer: B. Usually, vertical incision is used
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Usually, vertical incision is used SURGICAL TECHNIQUE OF THYROIDECTOMY: The patient lies supine with the neck extended. A skin crease incision is placed around the level of the cricoid cartilage. Sub platysmal flaps are raised to the extent that allows access to the goiter, often from thyroid notch to sternal notch. Plane between the larynx and superior pole is developed, and the branching divisions of the superior vascular pedicle are dissected. Gradually the superior pole is mobilized taking care not to dissect below the cricoid cartilage, at which point the RLN is at risk. The tracheoesophageal groove should not be entered as the RLN is yet identified. RLN is identified and confirmed by the anatomical location, direction of travel, and the nerve monitor, if in use. The pre-tracheal fascia condenses into Berry’s ligament at this stage. Small vessels within the ligament retract if not controlled with bipolar diathermy or ties, and the resulting bleeding can disorientate the surgeon placing the nerve at risk. If total thyroidectomy is indicated the procedure is repeated on the contralateral side. If lobectomy alone is indicated, the isthmus should be divided between clamps and oversewn. Consideration may be given to the reimplantation of parathyroids to the sternomastoid muscle if they appear devascularised. Following complete hemostasis, the strap muscles are loosely reapproximated to avoid a water-tight seal but to the recent adhesion between skin and trachea. The wound is then closed in layers with absorbable suture to platysma and skin closure.

Highyeild:

Thyroid surgery involves the removal of part or all of the thyroid gland. The most common surgical approach for thyroidectomy is a collar incision made horizontally across the neck crease . A vertical incision may be used in certain cases, such as when a large goiter or cancer involves the central part of the gland. For lobectomy , the thyroid isthmus is divided, and the lobe to be removed is dissected. The strap muscles are divided to provide greater exposure to the gland but are usually preserved to maintain neck function. Complications of thyroid surgery include bleeding, infection, nerve injury, and hypothyroidism.

questions.text: According to the AGES scoring system, the truth about low-risk patients of thyroid cancer is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Young age AGES scoring system, which incorporates Age, Histologic grade, Extrathyroidal invasion, metastases & tumors Size to predict the risk of dying from papillary cancer. Low-risk patients are young, with well-differentiated tumors, no metastases, and small primary lesions. High-risk patients are older, with poorly differentiated tumors, local invasion, distant metastases, and large primary lesions. AMES system to classify differentiated thyroid tumors into low & high-risk groups using Age (men <40 years old, women <50 years old), Metastases, Extrathyroidal spread, and Size of tumors (< or >5 cm). The MACIS scale is a postoperative system modified from the AGES scale. This scale incorporates distant Metastases, Age at presentation (<40 or >40 years old), Completeness of original surgical resection, extrathyroidal Invasion, and Size of the original lesion (in centimeters).

questions.text: True about lymphatic drainage of breast is/are:

options.label: A
options.text: Axillary nodes receive approximately 85% of the drainage

options.label: B
options.text: Level II nodes lie behind the Pectoralis minor

options.label: C
options.text: Guiliano node is the sentinel node for breast cancer

questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above The lymphatics of the breast drain predominantly into the axillary and internal mammary lymph nodes. The axillary nodes receive approximately 85% of the drainage. They are arranged in the following groups: lateral - along the axillary vein, anterior - along the lateral thoracic vessels, posterior - along the subscapular vessels, central - embedded in fat in the center of the axilla, interpectoral - a few nodes lying between the pectoralis major and minor muscles, apical , which lie above the level of the pectoralis minor tendon in continuity with the lateral nodes and which receive the efferents of all the other groups. Lymph nodes located lateral to or below the lower border of the pectoralis minor muscle are called level I lymph nodes, including the axillary vein, external mammary, and scapular groups. Lymph nodes located superficial or deep to the pectoralis minor muscle are called level II lymph nodes, including the main and interpectoral groups. Lymph nodes located medial to or above the upper border of the pectoralis minor muscle are called level III lymph nodes, consisting of the sub-clavicular group. Guiliano node is the sentinel node for breast cancer. The sentinel node is the first lymph node draining the tumor-bearing area of the breast.

questions.text: A 26 years old lady who is 9 weeks pregnant, comes with 2.5 cm mass in the upper outer quadrant of left breast. Ultrasound failed to show any abnormality. The ideal management will be?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Palpation guided core biopsy IOC for a palpable lump in the breast- FNAC or Biopsy . If the USG shows the lesion as a cystic lesion, aspirate the cyst and send the fluid for analysis. Histology can be obtained under local anesthesia using a spring-loaded core needle biopsy device. Cytology is obtained using a 21G or 23G needle and 10-mL syringe with multiple passes through the lump with negative pressure in the syringe. The aspirate is then smeared on a slide that is air-dried or fixed. A histological specimen taken by core biopsy allows a definitive preoperative diagnosis, differentiates between DCIS and invasive disease, and allows the tumor to be stained for receptor status. This is important before commencing neoadjuvant therapy.

questions.text: Blood- stained nipple discharge is seen in:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Duct papilloma Discharges from the nipple: Discharge can occur from one or more lactiferous ducts. Management depends on the presence of a lump (which should always be given priority in diagnosis and treatment) and the presence of blood in the discharge or discharge from a single duct. Mammography is rarely useful except to exclude an underlying impalpable mass. Cytology may reveal malignant cells, but a negative result does not exclude a carcinoma or in situ disease. A clear, serous discharge may be ‘physiological’ in a parous woman or associated with a duct papilloma or mammary dysplasia. Multi-duct, multicolored discharge is physiological, and the patient may be reassured. A blood-stained discharge may be caused by duct ectasia, a duct papilloma, or carcinoma. A duct papilloma is usually single and situated in one of the larger lactiferous ducts; it is sometimes associated with a cystic swelling beneath the areola. A black or green discharge is usually the result of duct ectasia and its complications.

questions.text: A 25-years old female complains of discharge of blood from a single duct in her breast. The most appropriate treatment is
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Microdochectomy MICRODOCHECTOMY: It is important not to express the blood before the operation as it may be difficult to identify the duct. A lacrimal probe or length of stiff nylon suture is inserted into the duct from which the discharge is emerging. A tennis racquet incision can encompass the entire duct, or a peri-areolar incision can be used and the nipple flap dissected to reach the duct. The duct is then excised. A papilloma is nearly always situated within 4–5cm of the nipple orifice. The affected duct may not be visualized, and biopsy systems are currently rudimentary. CONE EXCISION OF THE MAJOR DUCT (HADFIELD/SUBAREOLAR RESECTION): When the duct of origin of nipple bleeding is uncertain or when there is bleeding or discharge from multiple ducts, the entire central duct system can be excised for histological examination without the sacrifice of the breast form. A peri-areolar incision is made, and a cone of tissue is removed with its apex just deep to the surface of the nipple and its base on the pectoral fascia. A series of purse-string sutures may obliterate the resulting defect, although a temporary suction drain will reduce the chance of long-term deformity. It is vital to warn the patient that she will be unable to breastfeed after this and may experience altered nipple sensation.
